hero.title: Discover the real Peru with Mily
hero.subtitle: Clear, friendly guides about Peru‚Äôs history, food and destinations, created for curious travelers and tour guides.

bestDestinations.title: Featured destinations in Peru
bestDestinations.subtitle: A selection of places Mily knows very well and that are perfect for your first trip around Peru: history, sea, desert and culture.

limaCentro.title: Historic center of Lima
limaCentro.description: Colonial balconies, the Main Square and the most important churches in the old town.

barranco.title: Bohemian Barranco
barranco.description: Bridge of Sighs, murals, caf√©s and sunsets with ocean views.

circuitoMagico.title: Magic Water Circuit
circuitoMagico.description: Illuminated fountains, a night show and a classic plan to enjoy Lima after dark.

paracasHuacachina.title: Paracas & Ica ‚Äì Ballestas Islands and Huacachina
paracasHuacachina.description: Boat ride, desert, sand dunes and an oasis: one of the most famous full-day trips from Lima.

nazca.title: Nazca Lines
nazca.description: Mysterious figures seen from the air, one of Peru‚Äôs greatest enigmas.

museosLima.title: Museums and culture in Lima
museosLima.description: Larco Museum and other spaces that help you understand the country‚Äôs history better.

heroCarousel.sectionSubtitle: Three classics every traveler should try: lomo saltado, ceviche and Pisco Sour, explained in a simple and friendly way.

lomo.title: Lomo saltado: Peru in a frying pan
lomo.subtitle: Beef stir-fried in a hot wok with fries and white rice. One of the dishes that surprises travelers the most.

ceviche.title: Ceviche: a coastal classic
ceviche.subtitle: Fresh fish, lime, chili and red onion. Learn how to explain it and when it‚Äôs best to recommend it to your passengers.

pisco.title: Pisco sour: the perfect toast
pisco.subtitle: History, fun facts and tips to recommend bars and experiences where travelers can try Peru‚Äôs signature cocktail.

historyPreview.title: Peruvian history made simple
historyPreview.subtitle: Four key stages so you can explain Peru‚Äôs past without getting lost in dates and complicated names.

preinca.title: Pre-Inca period
preinca.description: Cultures like Caral, Paracas, Nazca or Moche set the foundations long before the Inca Empire.

inca.title: Inca Empire
inca.description: Cusco as the center of the world, an incredible road network, terraces and organized society.

virreinato.title: Viceroyalty of Peru
virreinato.description: The Spanish arrive, traditions mix and Lima becomes the most important city in South America.

republica.title: Independence and Republic
republica.description: Wars, changes and the slow construction of a Peruvian identity up to the country we know today.

aboutMini.title: Hi, I'm Mily, your guide in Peru
aboutMini.text: I'm an official tour guide and I love sharing Peru's history, culture and daily life with travelers from all over the world. This blog was born to help you understand what you see during your trips and to give other guides clear and useful explanations.

intro.title: Where to start discovering Peru?
intro.description: This blog is not an endless list of places, but a curated selection of routes that Mily knows well, has guided and truly recommends for a first trip to Peru.

lima.title: Lima: your natural starting point
lima.text: Historic center, bohemian districts and ocean views. Perfect to feel the mix of colonial and modern Peru.

surChico.title: Sur chico: sea, desert and adventure
surChico.text: Paracas, Ballestas Islands and Huacachina in one classic full day for wildlife, dunes and oasis lovers.

icaNazca.title: Ica & Nazca: wine, pisco and mysteries
icaNazca.text: Wineries, tastings and the enigmatic Nazca Lines if you want to go a bit further from Lima.

hero.title: Peruvian destinations Mily really knows
hero.subtitle: Perfect places for your first trip: ocean, desert, traditions and city life.
hero.alt: View of different travel destinations in Peru

limaHistoric.title: Your first walk through downtown Lima
limaHistoric.intro: An easy route to understand republican Lima: plazas, balconies, churches and iconic buildings you can visit on foot.

hotelBolivar.name: Gran Hotel Bol√≠var
hotelBolivar.description: Historic hotel facing San Mart√≠n Square, known for its architecture and classic pisco sour.
hotelBolivar.schedule: Nice to visit in the afternoon or evening when the square is lit up.
hotelBolivar.price: Free access to the lobby; food and drinks are paid separately.

plazaSanMartin.name: San Mart√≠n Square
plazaSanMartin.description: One of Lima‚Äôs main squares and the perfect starting point for your downtown walk.

jironUnion.name: Jir√≥n de la Uni√≥n
jironUnion.description: The pedestrian street that connects San Mart√≠n Square with the Main Square, full of old buildings and local life.
jironUnion.schedule: Great to walk during the day and around sunset.

plazaArmas.name: Main Square of Lima
plazaArmas.description: The political and religious heart of the city, surrounded by colonial balconies and government buildings.
plazaArmas.schedule: Recommended both during the day and at night.

catedralLima.name: Lima Cathedral
catedralLima.description: The main church of the city, with historic tombs and a small museum inside.
catedralLima.schedule: Usually opens in the morning and early afternoon (check updated schedule).
catedralLima.price: Paid entrance to the museum; quick visits to the temple may be free at certain times.

palacioGobierno.name: Government Palace
palacioGobierno.description: The seat of the Peruvian presidency, known for its facade and the changing of the guard.
palacioGobierno.schedule: The changing of the guard is usually around noon (check the current time).
palacioGobierno.price: Seeing the facade and square is free.

mirafloresCoast.title: A walk through Miraflores viewpoints
mirafloresCoast.intro: An easy route along the Miraflores cliff walk: ocean viewpoints, parks, romantic spots and an open-air mall with views over the Costa Verde.

parqueMariaReiche.name: Mar√≠a Reiche Park
parqueMariaReiche.description: Park overlooking the Costa Verde dedicated to Mar√≠a Reiche, the researcher of the Nazca Lines. There are small models of the figures and several viewpoints.
parqueMariaReiche.schedule: Morning or afternoon, with good light to see the models and the cliffs.

parqueChino.name: Chinese Park
parqueChino.description: Small themed park with a pagoda, Chinese-inspired details and a different angle of the Miraflores seafront.
parqueChino.schedule: Afternoon, great for photos with soft light.

parqueAmor.name: Parque del Amor (Love Park)
parqueAmor.description: One of Miraflores‚Äô most iconic spots. The sculpture ‚ÄúEl Beso‚Äù and the mosaic benches are perfect for watching the sunset over the Pacific Ocean.
parqueAmor.schedule: Sunset time to enjoy the view and take photos.

parqueIntihuatana.name: Intihuatana Park
parqueIntihuatana.description: Park with a sun-clock inspired by Andean cultures and a wide view over the Miraflores cliffs.
parqueIntihuatana.schedule: Afternoon, while there is still sun to see the clock and the coastline.

larcomar.name: Larcomar Mall
larcomar.description: Open-air shopping center built on the cliffs. Stores, restaurants and terraces with views over the Costa Verde.
larcomar.schedule: Late afternoon and evening. You can combine shopping, dinner and night views.
larcomar.price: Free entrance; you only pay for what you consume.

puenteVillena.name: Villena Bridge ("glass bridge")
puenteVillena.description: Pedestrian bridge with glass panels linking sections of the Miraflores cliff walk and offering great views towards the Costa Verde and the way to Barranco.
puenteVillena.schedule: Sunset or night, when the bridge and the coast lights are on.

barranco.title: A walk between murals, music and the ocean in Barranco
barranco.intro: Start in a quiet park, pass by monuments, streets with live music and end between viewpoints and lively plazas.

parqueVillarreal.name: Federico Villarreal Park
parqueVillarreal.description: A small, quiet park to start your route, with trees and benches where you can plan the rest of your walk.
parqueVillarreal.schedule: Morning or afternoon, ideal as a meeting point.

monumentoChabuca.name: Chabuca Granda Monument
monumentoChabuca.description: Monument dedicated to Barranco‚Äôs most beloved singer-songwriter, author of the famous song ‚ÄúLa flor de la canela‚Äù.
monumentoChabuca.schedule: All day; especially nice at sunset with soft light.

puenteSuspiros.name: Bridge of Sighs
puenteSuspiros.description: Barranco‚Äôs classic spot: a wooden bridge with graffiti, street musicians and a view towards the path down to the sea.
puenteSuspiros.schedule: Late afternoon or evening to feel the bohemian atmosphere.

bajadaBanos.name: Bajada de Ba√±os
bajadaBanos.description: Pedestrian street that goes down towards the sea, full of murals, bars and restaurants. From here you can reach the viewpoint or continue all the way to the coast.
bajadaBanos.schedule: Afternoon or evening, when most places are open.
bajadaBanos.price: Free access; food and drinks are paid separately.

miradorRecavarren.name: Catalina Recavarren Viewpoint
miradorRecavarren.description: Viewpoint over the cliffs and the Pacific Ocean, perfect for photos at sunset.
miradorRecavarren.schedule: Best at sunset, when you can see the colors of the sky and city lights.

parqueMunicipal.name: Barranco Main Square
parqueMunicipal.description: The district‚Äôs main square, surrounded by old houses, restaurants and the Church of the Holy Cross.
parqueMunicipal.schedule: Morning or night; there is usually movement at any time.

waterCircuit.title: An evening of lights, water and music at Parque de la Reserva
waterCircuit.intro: The Magic Water Circuit is built inside the historic Parque de la Reserva, right in front of the National Stadium. It‚Äôs a perfect plan for a late afternoon and evening in Lima.

estadio.name: National Stadium (outside view)
estadio.description: Before entering the Magic Water Circuit you can walk past the National Stadium, Peru‚Äôs most important football stadium.
estadio.schedule: Best around sunset, when the city lights start to turn on.
estadio.price: Outside view only; this route usually does not include going inside the stadium.

parque.name: Parque de la Reserva ‚Äì Magic Water Circuit
parque.description: The old Parque de la Reserva, now transformed into a circuit of illuminated fountains with music, photo spots and a family-friendly atmosphere.
parque.schedule: Late afternoon and evening. A good idea is to enter while there is still daylight and stay until it gets dark.
parque.price: Paid entrance. Prices may change over time; check the official website or ask at the ticket office.

waterCircuit.fountainsTitle: The 13 fountains of the Magic Water Circuit
waterCircuit.fountainsIntro: Inside the park you‚Äôll find 13 interactive and decorative fountains. Here are the most famous ones so you know what not to miss.

fantasia.name: Fuente de la Fantas√≠a
fantasia.description: The most famous fountain, where Peruvian images and history are projected onto a water screen with music, lights and lasers.

laberinto.name: Laberinto del Ensue√±o
laberinto.description: A small water maze where you can try to walk in and out without getting wet‚Ä¶ if you choose the right moment.

tunelSorpresas.name: Tunnel of Surprises
tunelSorpresas.description: A tunnel formed by arches of water. Great for romantic photos and for walking while listening to the sound of the fountains.

ninos.name: Children‚Äôs Fountain
ninos.description: Area designed for kids to play and splash around. Bring extra clothes if you‚Äôre visiting with family.

armonia.name: Fountain of Harmony
armonia.description: Calmer, decorative fountains that are perfect for photos with the buildings of central Lima in the background.

arcoIris.name: Rainbow Fountain
arcoIris.description: Water jets that form colourful arches thanks to the night lighting.

magica.name: Magic Fountain
magica.description: One of the main fountains, with tall jets that change intensity with the music.

ilusion.name: Fountain of Illusion
ilusion.description: Jets that appear and disappear, creating visual effects that look great in videos and photos.

cupula.name: Visitor‚Äôs Dome Fountain
cupula.description: A dome made of water where you can stand in the middle and see the city through the curtain of jets.

rioDeseos.name: River of Wishes
rioDeseos.description: A small illuminated canal where many visitors take photos and make a wish.

vida.name: Fountain of Life
vida.description: Design that represents movement and energy, with jets at different heights.

union.name: Fountain of Union
union.description: Water jets that cross and meet in the centre, symbolising people coming together.

tradiciones.name: Traditions Fountain
tradiciones.description: Decorative fountain usually surrounded by Peruvian music, from criollo to Andean tunes.

logia.name: Monument of the Lodge
logia.description: Fountain next to an elegant classic-style loggia with columns and arches, especially photogenic at night when both the water and the architecture are lit up.

icaNazca.title: Classic south route: Ballestas Islands, Huacachina & Nazca Lines
icaNazca.intro: A route designed to make the most of a full day from Lima or a short 2-day trip: ocean, desert, wineries and one of the greatest mysteries of the ancient world.

buttons.tour: I want this tour with Mily

ballestas.name: Paracas ‚Äì Ballestas Islands
ballestas.description: Boat ride in Paracas Bay to see sea lions, guano birds, Humboldt penguins and the famous Candelabro geoglyph etched into the coastal desert.
ballestas.schedule: Early morning (most tours depart between 8:00 and 10:00 a.m.).
ballestas.price: Boat tour + port and reserve fees (prices vary by agency).

icaBodega.name: Ica ‚Äì Winery visit & lunch
icaBodega.description: Visit a traditional winery to learn about the production of wine and pisco. Guided tasting and typical lunch. You can go to wineries like Nieto, CulturPisco or other well-known spots in the area.
icaBodega.schedule: Around midday, after the Ballestas Islands tour.
icaBodega.price: Tasting and lunch according to menu or daily specials.
icaBodega.duration: 1.5‚Äì2 hours including tour, tasting and meal.

huacachina.name: Huacachina Oasis & dune buggies
huacachina.description: A natural oasis surrounded by huge sand dunes. Here you do the classic dune buggy ride and sandboarding with a beautiful desert sunset.
huacachina.schedule: Afternoon, ideally arriving before 4:00 p.m. to catch the sunset.
huacachina.price: Dune buggy and sandboard; paid per circuit or per person depending on the operator.
huacachina.duration: 1‚Äì2 hours depending on the tour you choose.

nazcaLines.name: Nazca Lines flight
nazcaLines.description: Light-aircraft flight over the mysterious figures drawn in the desert: the hummingbird, the monkey, the spider and many more. Usually done as an extension of the trip, leaving very early from Ica or spending the night in Nazca.
nazcaLines.schedule: Very early in the morning. You must arrive in advance at the airfield for check-in.
nazcaLines.price: Flight + airport fee; prices vary depending on season and local airline.
nazcaLines.duration: 30‚Äì40 minute flight, but plan at least 2‚Äì3 hours including waiting and paperwork.

icaNazca.outro: You can do this south route as an intense full-day trip from Lima or split it into 2 days to travel more relaxed. If you‚Äôd like Mily to help you organize it, send us a message on the contact page.

hero.title: Peruvian cuisine Mily has tasted
hero.subtitle: From coastal ceviches to Andean dishes: an honest guide to eating well.

intro.title: Flavors born from the coast, the Andes and the Amazon
intro.subtitle: Peruvian cuisine is considered one of the best in the world thanks to its ingredients, techniques and cultural mix. Here you‚Äôll find a clear guide by regions so you can explain it to travelers without getting lost in details.
intro.paragraph1: In a single country you get products from the Pacific Ocean, the Andes mountains and the Amazon rainforest. On top of that, there are centuries of history: Indigenous heritage plus Spanish, African, Chinese, Japanese and Italian influence. The result is a very diverse cuisine, but with something in common: intense flavors and dishes that tell stories.
intro.paragraph2: To make it easier to learn and to explain, in this blog we divide Peruvian food into three big families: dishes from the coast, the Andes and the Amazon. In each one you‚Äôll see concrete examples, tips to explain them to tourists and simple historical context.

coast.label: Coast: seafood, ceviche & anticuchos
coast.description: Dishes made with fresh fish and seafood, chili peppers, corn and potatoes. This is where ceviche, tiradito, lomo saltado and many of the classics that travelers try in Lima and coastal cities are born.

andes.label: Andes: potatoes, quinoa & stews
andes.description: Heartier soups and stews with native potatoes, quinoa, corn, meat and ancestral techniques. Perfect for colder regions like Cusco, Puno or Ayacucho.

jungle.label: Amazon: bold flavors and bijao leaves
jungle.description: Dishes wrapped in leaves, with plantain, cecina (smoked pork), sausages, river fish and exotic fruits. An aromatic and colorful cuisine that surprises visitors to the Peruvian Amazon.

intro.next: In the next sections you‚Äôll see concrete examples from each region, starting with the most famous dishes from the coast and then traveling to the Andes and the Amazon.

coast.title: Flavors of Peru‚Äôs coastal region
coast.intro: Along the Peruvian coast, the cold Pacific Ocean meets Andean and Creole ingredients. Here you‚Äôll find ceviches, rice dishes, causas and drinks that have become famous worldwide.

ceviche.name: Classic Peruvian ceviche
ceviche.tagline: Fresh fish, lime juice, and chili: the perfect combination to understand coastal Peruvian cuisine.
ceviche.ingredients: Fresh white fish (such as bonito or corvina), freshly squeezed lime juice, aj√≠ limo chili, sliced red onion, chopped cilantro, salt, pepper, boiled sweet potato, corn, and cancha (toasted corn) on the side.
ceviche.preparation: Cut the fish into cubes and season with salt, pepper, chili, and cilantro. Add the freshly squeezed lime juice, mix gently, and let it rest just a few minutes until the fish turns opaque. Serve immediately with onion, sweet potato, corn, and cancha.

lecheTigre.name: Leche de tigre
lecheTigre.tagline: The concentrated juice of ceviche, served in a glass as an energizing shot, perfect for hot days.
lecheTigre.ingredients: Lime juice, fish stock, leftover ceviche juices, small pieces of fish, aj√≠ limo chili, garlic, cilantro, salt, and pepper. Sometimes a splash of ginger ale or crushed ice is added to make it extra refreshing.
lecheTigre.preparation: Blend the lime juice with fish stock, some of the ceviche fish, chili, garlic, and cilantro. Strain, adjust seasoning with salt and pepper, and serve very cold in a small glass, garnished with onion, chili, and a cube of fish if you like.
lecheTigre.historyCta: Read the story of leche de tigre

arrozMariscos.name: Arroz con mariscos (seafood rice)
arrozMariscos.tagline: A creamy rice packed with seafood, perfect as a main dish after ceviche.
arrozMariscos.ingredients: Rice, fish stock, mixed seafood (squid, octopus, shellfish, shrimp), garlic, onion, aj√≠ amarillo and aj√≠ panca chilies, white wine, chopped cilantro, peas, bell pepper, salt, and pepper.
arrozMariscos.preparation: Make a base with onion, garlic, and chilies. Sear the seafood over high heat, then add the rice and hot stock. Cook until the rice is tender but still juicy, then finish with cilantro, strips of bell pepper, and a few drops of lime juice.
arrozMariscos.historyCta: Read the story of arroz con mariscos

causaLangostinos.name: Causa filled with shrimp
causaLangostinos.tagline: Layers of seasoned yellow potato with a shrimp filling, freshness, and a lot of texture.
causaLangostinos.ingredients: Mashed yellow potatoes, aj√≠ amarillo chili paste, vegetable oil, lime juice, salt, cooked shrimp, mayonnaise, avocado, hard-boiled egg, lettuce, and olives to decorate.
causaLangostinos.preparation: Mix the mashed potatoes with aj√≠ amarillo, oil, lime, and salt until smooth. Assemble in layers: potato, shrimp and mayo filling with avocado, and another layer of potato. Decorate with egg, olives, and whole shrimp on top.

piscoSour.name: Peruvian pisco sour
piscoSour.tagline: A cocktail made with pisco, lime, simple syrup, and egg white, perfect to start the evening.
piscoSour.ingredients: Peruvian pisco (such as quebranta), fresh lime juice, simple syrup, egg white, and ice. A few drops of Angostura bitters are added on top.
piscoSour.preparation: In a shaker or blender, mix pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, egg white, and ice. Shake or blend until a thick foam forms, then serve in a chilled glass and add a few drops of bitters on the foam.
piscoSour.historyCta: Read the story of pisco sour

chichaMorada.name: Chicha morada
chichaMorada.tagline: A sweet, aromatic drink made from purple corn, fruit, and spices.
chichaMorada.ingredients: Purple corn, pineapple (peel and core), apple, cinnamon sticks, cloves, sugar or panela, lime juice, and water.
chichaMorada.preparation: Boil the purple corn with pineapple peel, apple, cinnamon, and cloves for several minutes. Strain and let it cool, then sweeten to taste. Just before serving, add lime juice to bring freshness.
chichaMorada.historyCta: Read the story of chicha morada

recommendations.title: Where to try these flavors in Lima
recommendations.subtitle: If you want to try ceviche and other coastal dishes in Lima, these places are a good starting point. Remember there are many local huariques that Mily can recommend to you in person.

puntoAzul.note: Very popular cevicher√≠a among locals, with generous portions and a relaxed atmosphere.

laMar.note: Gast√≥n Acurio‚Äôs cevicher√≠a, ideal if you want a more gourmet experience and a wide variety of ceviches.

mercado.note: Modern restaurant where ceviche is served with creative touches and very fresh seafood.

alFresco.note: A classic spot facing the ocean, perfect to enjoy ceviche with a Costa Verde view.

huarique.note: Small neighborhood spots where ceviche is simple, direct, and tastes like home cooking.

sierra.title: Flavors of the Peruvian highlands
sierra.intro: Hearty dishes, hot soups and rustic drinks born from the cold of the Andes. Recipes with potatoes, corn and meats that have nourished Andean families for generations.

buttons.history: Read the story of this dish or drink

cuyChactado.name: Cuy chactado (fried guinea pig)
cuyChactado.ingredients: Whole guinea pig marinated with garlic, aj√≠ panca, salt, pepper, cumin and plenty of fat for frying.
cuyChactado.preparation: The guinea pig is marinated, lightly flattened and fried in hot fat until it becomes very crunchy.

pachamanca.name: Pachamanca
pachamanca.ingredients: Mixed meats (chicken, pork, beef, sometimes cuy), potatoes, sweet potato, broad beans, corn and Andean herbs such as chincho and huacatay.
pachamanca.preparation: Stones are heated in an earth oven, the marinated meats and tubers are placed inside, covered with herbs and earth and cooked slowly with the heat of the stones.

rocotoRelleno.name: Rocoto relleno (stuffed hot pepper)
rocotoRelleno.ingredients: Rocoto peppers without seeds, ground meat, peanuts, raisins, fresh cheese, milk and spices.
rocotoRelleno.preparation: The rocotos are blanched to reduce the heat, stuffed with a seasoned meat filling, topped with cheese and baked until golden.

chicharronMote.name: Chicharr√≥n with mote
chicharronMote.ingredients: Pork, salt, aromatic herbs and cooked peeled corn (mote).
chicharronMote.preparation: The pork is cooked in its own fat until golden and served with mote, potatoes and simple salads.

truchaFrita.name: Fried trout
truchaFrita.ingredients: Fresh trout, garlic, salt, pepper, flour or cornstarch and oil for frying.
truchaFrita.preparation: The trout is seasoned, lightly floured and fried until crispy on the outside and juicy inside. It is served with potatoes and salad.

sopaMote.name: Mote soup
sopaMote.ingredients: Peeled corn (mote), beef or pork, potatoes, herbs and vegetables.
sopaMote.preparation: The mote is slowly cooked together with the meats and vegetables until you get a thick, very hot soup.

caldoCabeza.name: Head soup
caldoCabeza.ingredients: Sheep‚Äôs head, potatoes, mint, garlic, onion and spices.
caldoCabeza.preparation: The head is boiled for several hours with potatoes and herbs, resulting in a very rich and comforting broth.

patasca.name: Patasca
patasca.ingredients: Peeled corn (mote), beef or pork, tripe, potatoes and herbs.
patasca.preparation: Corn and meats are simmered for a long time until everything is tender; it is served very hot, almost like a thick stew.

quesoHelado.name: Arequipe√±o queso helado
quesoHelado.ingredients: Milk, sugar, egg yolks (sometimes), cinnamon, vanilla and grated coconut.
quesoHelado.preparation: The milk mixture is frozen in a metal cylinder and scraped to form thin layers, similar to a creamy shaved ice.

calentito.name: Calentito
calentito.ingredients: Cane liquor, herbal tea, sugar or honey and sometimes lemon juice.
calentito.preparation: Hot herbal infusion is mixed with liquor and sugar, and served in a small glass ‚Äì a classic drink for cold Andean nights.

chichaJora.name: Chicha de jora
chichaJora.ingredients: Jora corn (fermented), water and sometimes panela or fruit.
chichaJora.preparation: The corn is soaked, cooked and left to ferment for several days. It is strained and served as a slightly sour, foamy drink.

places.title: Where to taste Andean flavors in Lima?
places.intro: If you want to try cuy, pachamanca or other highland dishes without leaving Lima, these restaurants are a good place to start.

panchita.name: Panchita (Miraflores)
panchita.description: Criollo restaurant with Andean influences; you can find chicharr√≥n, anticuchos and hearty dishes from the highlands.

elRocoto.name: El Rocoto (Miraflores / San Isidro)
elRocoto.description: Classic Arequipa-style restaurant in Lima, famous for its rocoto relleno and other southern dishes.

laCusquenita.name: La Cusque√±ita (Lince)
laCusquenita.description: Traditional spot with live music some nights, serving cuy chactado, chicharr√≥n with mote, soups and chicha de jora.

huancahuasi.name: Huancahuasi (Ate / Los Olivos)
huancahuasi.description: Specialized in Huancayo-style food and pachamanca; perfect to share typical Andean dishes with family or friends.

places.note: Opening hours and menus may change; check each restaurant‚Äôs website or social media before visiting.

selva.title: Flavors of the Peruvian Amazon
selva.intro: Dishes wrapped in leaves, river fish, exotic fruits and fermented drinks. Amazonian cuisine surprises with its intense aromas and vibrant colors.

buttons.history: Read the story of this dish or drink

juane.name: Juane
juane.ingredients: Rice, chicken, olives, hard-boiled egg, spices and bijao leaves for wrapping.
juane.preparation: Rice is mixed with shredded chicken and spices, wrapped in bijao leaves to form a packet and boiled for several hours until everything is compact.

patarashca.name: Patarashca
patarashca.ingredients: River fish (such as paiche or doncella), garlic, cilantro, aj√≠ charapita, salt and bijao leaves.
patarashca.preparation: The fish is seasoned with garlic, cilantro and chili, wrapped in bijao leaves and grilled over charcoal until cooked and aromatic.

tacacho.name: Tacacho with cecina
tacacho.ingredients: Roasted green plantain, lard, salt, cecina (smoked pork) and regional chorizo.
tacacho.preparation: The plantain is roasted, mashed with lard and salt to form balls, and served with grilled cecina and chorizo.

suriFrito.name: Fried suri
suriFrito.ingredients: Suris (beetle larvae), salt, garlic and oil for frying.
suriFrito.preparation: The suris are cleaned, seasoned with salt and garlic, and fried until crispy on the outside and creamy inside.

inchicapi.name: Inchicapi
inchicapi.ingredients: Free-range hen, roasted and ground peanuts, cassava, cilantro, garlic, cumin and salt.
inchicapi.preparation: The hen is cooked with ground peanuts to form a thick, creamy soup, then cassava and cilantro are added at the end.

chilicano.name: Chilicano
chilicano.ingredients: Fresh river fish, cilantro, garlic, onion, aj√≠ charapita, lime and salt.
chilicano.preparation: A light broth is made with the fish, cilantro, garlic and chili, served very hot with freshly squeezed lime juice.

cecina.name: Amazonian cecina
cecina.ingredients: Pork, coarse salt, spices and smoking time.
cecina.preparation: The meat is heavily salted and smoked for several days, then grilled until golden and aromatic.

timbuche.name: Timbuche
timbuche.ingredients: River fish, fish eggs, cilantro, onion, aj√≠ charapita and salt.
timbuche.preparation: The fish is cooked with its eggs in water with cilantro and chili, forming a simple but very nutritious soup.

cremoladaAguaje.name: Aguaje cremolada
cremoladaAguaje.ingredients: Aguaje pulp, sugar, water and ice.
cremoladaAguaje.preparation: Aguaje pulp is blended with sugar and water, then frozen while scraping constantly to form a creamy shaved ice texture.

masato.name: Masato
masato.ingredients: Cooked and chewed (or blended) cassava, water, sugar and fermentation time.
masato.preparation: Cassava is cooked, mashed or chewed, mixed with water and sugar and left to ferment for days to obtain a slightly sour drink.

chapo.name: Chapo
chapo.ingredients: Ripe plantain, water, sugar or panela and cinnamon.
chapo.preparation: Ripe plantain is cooked with water and sugar to form a thick, sweet drink, served cold or hot.

aguajina.name: Aguajina
aguajina.ingredients: Aguaje pulp, water, sugar and ice.
aguajina.preparation: Aguaje pulp is blended with water and sugar, strained and served very cold as a nutritious refreshment.

places.title: Where to try Amazonian flavors in Lima?
places.intro: If you want to try juane, patarashca and other Amazon dishes without leaving Lima, these restaurants are a good place to start.

malabar.name: Malabar (San Isidro)
malabar.description: Fine dining restaurant with Amazonian proposals, ideal for discovering ingredients from the jungle with a gourmet presentation.

amaz.name: Amaz (Miraflores)
amaz.description: Specialized in contemporary Amazonian cuisine, with dishes like patarashca, tacacho and exotic drinks.

laPatarashca.name: La Patarashca (multiple locations)
laPatarashca.description: Cevicher√≠a chain with a strong presence of Amazonian fish and typical dishes from the jungle.

elRinconcito.name: El Rinconcito Amaz√≥nico (San Juan de Lurigancho)
elRinconcito.description: Popular restaurant serving juane, cecina, tacacho and other homestyle preparations from the Amazon.

places.note: Opening hours and menus may change; check each restaurant's website or social media before visiting.

hero.title: Peruvian history told by Mily
hero.subtitle: From the Incas to today: the stories that shape this country.

intro.title: From pre-Inca cultures to the Republic
intro.subtitle: A quick overview of the main stages in Peru‚Äôs history. Tap each block to jump straight to the detailed section.

preinca.title: Before the Incas: cultures that made the Empire possible
preinca.subtitle: Long before Cusco became the capital of the Inca Empire, cities, temples and skilled artisans already existed along the Andes. This period brings together the cultures that prepared the ground for the Andean world.

tags.focus: Regional cultures, temples, textiles and farming systems

keyIdeas.title: Key takeaways
keyIdeas.lead: If you only have a few minutes to explain the Pre-Inca period, focus on these ideas.

bullets.one: There was no single empire yet, but many regional cultures with their own styles.
bullets.two: They built temples, pyramids and ceremonial centers that organized religious and political life.
bullets.three: They developed textiles, pottery and irrigation systems later adopted by the Incas.

timeline.title: Quick timeline
timeline.lead: Four moments to help you place Pre-Inca cultures in time.

caral.label: Caral
caral.description: One of the oldest cities in the Americas, with pyramids and sunken plazas in the Supe Valley (Lima).

chavin.label: Chav√≠n
chavin.description: Religious center whose stone and ceramic art influenced many other Andean cultures.

nazcaMoche.label: Nazca & Moche
nazcaMoche.description: Nazca created the famous desert geoglyphs; Moche built huacas and detailed pottery that shows daily life and rituals.

wariChimu.label: Wari & Chim√∫
wariChimu.description: Wari planned cities and roads; Chim√∫ built Chan Chan, a huge adobe city near today‚Äôs Trujillo.

cultures.title: Key cultures to mention
cultures.lead: You don‚Äôt need to memorize a long list. These are the names that most often appear in museums, tours and conversations with travelers.

caral.name: Caral
caral.description: Sacred city with pyramids and circular plazas, very early urban planning for the Americas.

chavin.name: Chav√≠n
chavin.description: Sanctuary famous for the Lanz√≥n monolith and underground galleries.

paracas.name: Paracas
paracas.description: Known for its funerary bundles, extremely fine textiles and intentional cranial deformation.

nazca.name: Nazca
nazca.description: Creators of the Nazca Lines, huge figures drawn on the desert floor, best seen from the air.

moche.name: Moche
moche.description: Built large adobe temples and produced pottery that works almost like a graphic novel of their society.

wari.name: Wari
wari.description: Developed planned cities and a road network that later influenced Inca organization.

chimu.name: Chim√∫
chimu.description: Their capital Chan Chan is one of the largest adobe cities in the world.

life.title: What life was like in Pre-Inca times

society.title: Society
society.text: People lived in villages and ceremonial centers. Religious and political elites organized work and rituals, while specialized artisans produced pottery and textiles.

economy.title: Economy
economy.text: Agriculture in valleys and oases was the base, supported by irrigation canals. It was combined with coastal fishing and exchange routes between coast, highlands and jungle.

religion.title: Religion & worldview
religion.text: They worshipped forces of nature such as the sea, mountains and stars. Temples and huacas were the spaces for offerings, sacrifices and festivities.

sites.title: Where to see Pre-Inca heritage today
sites.lead: These sites are a good starting point if you want to connect this history with real places.

caral.name: Sacred City of Caral
caral.description: Archaeological complex with pyramids and sunken plazas, perfect to talk about the origins of cities in the Americas.

paracas.name: Paracas ‚Äì Necropolis & textiles
paracas.description: Museums and archaeological zones that display funerary bundles and detailed textiles.

nazca.name: Nazca Lines
nazca.description: Geoglyphs usually seen on small plane flights; great moment to talk about Andean symbolism and astronomy.

museoLarco.name: Larco Museum
museoLarco.description: Very complete collection of pottery and textiles from several Pre-Inca cultures, a perfect overview.

tips.title: Tips for explaining this period
tips.lead: Designed for guides and curious travelers who want to explain history without overwhelming people.

items.ideaStory1: Compare Caral with other civilizations from a similar time (Egypt, Mesopotamia) so visitors understand how old it is.
items.ideaStory2: When talking about Paracas and Nazca, link textile designs and geoglyphs with patterns still used in Peruvian crafts and fashion.
items.curiosity1: Some huacas continued to be worshipped even under Inca and later colonial rule.
items.curiosity2: Many Pre-Inca exchange routes were later reused to build the Inca road system.

tips.footer: Use these ideas as a guide, not a strict script. Adapt them to your style and to the time you have.

inca.title: The Tahuantinsuyo: empire of the four quarters
inca.subtitle: In just over a century the Incas went from a small kingdom in Cusco to ruling a territory from Colombia to central Chile. Here is a clear version of how that empire worked.

tags.focus: Expansion, state organization and major works

keyIdeas.title: Key points
keyIdeas.lead: Whenever you talk about the Inca period, try to come back to these three ideas.

bullets.one: The Incas did not appear from nowhere: they inherited knowledge from many earlier cultures.
bullets.two: They organized a highly centralized state with its capital in Cusco and a labor tax system known as mita.
bullets.three: They built roads, terraces and stone cities that today are icons of Peru, such as Machu Picchu.

timeline.title: Quick timeline
timeline.lead: Four moments to place the rise and fall of the Inca Empire.

origins.label: Cusco kingdoms
origins.description: Small lordships in the Cusco valley gradually consolidate their power before the imperial expansion.

pachacutec.label: Pachac√∫tec‚Äôs reign
pachacutec.description: Reorganizes Cusco, starts the expansion and is often associated with the construction of Machu Picchu.

expansion.label: Maximum expansion
expansion.description: Under T√∫pac Yupanqui and Huayna C√°pac the empire stretches from southern Colombia to central Chile.

crisis.label: Civil war & conquest
crisis.description: Huayna C√°pac‚Äôs death leads to a war between Hu√°scar and Atahualpa, weakening the empire when the Spanish arrive.

structure.title: How the Tahuantinsuyo worked
structure.lead: A short explanation of the imperial structure that you can adapt to any group.

territory.title: Territory and suyos
territory.text: The Tahuantinsuyo was divided into four regions or suyos (Chinchaysuyo, Antisuyo, Collasuyo and Contisuyo) connected by roads and administered from Cusco.

government.title: Government and mita
government.text: The Inca was the highest authority, supported by Cusco nobility. Conquered peoples had to provide labor tribute (mita) to build roads, terraces, temples and state storehouses.

roads.title: Roads and quipus
roads.text: The Qhapaq √ëan was a huge road network linking mountains, coast and jungle. Chasquis (runners) carried messages, and quipus were used to record censuses, tribute and storage.

religion.title: Religion and symbols
religion.text: The sun (Inti) was the main deity, but local huacas, mountains and Pachamama were also worshipped. The Incas usually incorporated local cults instead of destroying them.

people.title: People
people.text: Most inhabitants lived in ayllus, communities that shared land and work. Local identity coexisted with the idea of belonging to the Tahuantinsuyo.

work.title: Work & agriculture
work.text: Terraces and irrigation canals allowed farming on steep slopes. People worked in turns: time for the community, for the State and for the temples.

festivals.title: Festivals & rituals
festivals.text: Major ceremonies such as Inti Raymi marked the agricultural calendar. Offerings, dances and feasts reinforced loyalty to the Inca and the huacas.

sites.title: Places where the Inca world is still visible
sites.lead: These sites are excellent excuses to talk about the empire during a tour.

machuPicchu.name: Machu Picchu
machuPicchu.description: Mountain-top Inca city with agricultural and urban sectors. Perfect to explain Inca architecture and the relationship with the landscape.

sacsayhuaman.name: Sacsayhuam√°n
sacsayhuaman.description: Ceremonial fortress with huge stone blocks fitted with great precision, ideal to talk about engineering and defense.

qorikancha.name: Qorikancha
qorikancha.description: Main temple of the sun, later covered by the Santo Domingo convent. A clear example of Inca‚Äìcolonial overlap.

ollantaytambo.name: Ollantaytambo
ollantaytambo.description: Living town with Inca street layout, terraces and ceremonial sector. Shows how cities and storehouses were organized.

tips.title: Tips for explaining the Inca world
tips.lead: Use them to adapt your explanation to the group and the time you have.

items.ideaStory1: Start from what visitors see: ask them to look at terraces or stone walls and then explain how work and mita were organized.
items.ideaStory2: Relate the Qhapaq √ëan to modern highways or trekking routes (Inca Trail) so visitors can imagine its scale.
items.curiosity1: The Incas often adopted local huacas into their religious system instead of destroying them, gaining allies in the process.
items.curiosity2: In many colonial cities such as Cusco, the foundations of buildings are still Inca walls with Spanish houses and churches on top.

tips.footer: You don‚Äôt need to say everything in one tour. Choose a few ideas and repeat them at different stops.

virreinato.title: The Viceroyalty of Peru: wealth, control and cultural mixing
virreinato.subtitle: For almost 300 years the Viceroyalty of Peru was the main center of Spanish power in South America. This is the moment to explain mining, colonial cities, the caste system and the origins of many Peruvian traditions.

tags.focus: Mining, colonial cities and caste society

keyIdeas.title: Key points
keyIdeas.lead: If you have little time, stick to these three key ideas about the Viceroyalty.

bullets.one: Lima became the most important political and administrative capital in South America.
bullets.two: The economy was organized around silver mining, especially Potos√≠, and the forced labor of Indigenous people and enslaved Africans.
bullets.three: A caste society was created with strong hierarchies, but also with intense cultural mixing that shaped modern Peru.

timeline.title: Quick timeline
timeline.lead: Four moments that help visitors locate the history of the Viceroyalty.

conquest.label: Conquest of the Inca Empire
conquest.description: Atahualpa is captured and the Spanish enter Cusco. The Andean world changes forever.

limaCapital.label: Creation of the Viceroyalty of Peru
limaCapital.description: The Spanish Crown creates the Viceroyalty with its capital in the City of Kings (Lima).

borbonReforms.label: Bourbon reforms
borbonReforms.description: New rules to increase control and taxes. Tensions grow between the Crown and local elites.

independenceMovements.label: Rebellions & independence
independenceMovements.description: T√∫pac Amaru II‚Äôs rebellion and other uprisings pave the way for Peru‚Äôs independence.

structure.title: How the Viceroyalty worked
structure.lead: A simple explanation that you can expand depending on the group.

power.title: Power and authorities
power.text: The King of Spain was the highest authority. In America the viceroy ruled, supported by audiencias, local officials and town councils. In practice, local elites also had a lot of influence.

economy.title: Mining economy
economy.text: Silver from Potos√≠ and other mines financed the Spanish empire. Forced labor systems such as the mining mita affected thousands of Indigenous people.

society.title: Caste society
society.text: Population was classified by origin: peninsular Spaniards, criollos, Indigenous people, enslaved Africans and mixed groups. Everyday life, however, was far more complex and mixed than any list.

church.title: Church and cultural control
church.text: The Catholic Church evangelized, educated and also watched over ideas considered dangerous. At the same time, many devotions and festivals mixed Indigenous, African and European traditions.

city.title: Cities and main squares
city.text: In cities like Lima, the main square was the center of power: cathedral, government palace and houses of important families surrounded it.

countryside.title: Countryside and haciendas
countryside.text: In the countryside, large estates produced food and livestock. Many Indigenous people worked there under different forms of dependence.

mixing.title: Cultural mixing
mixing.text: Food, music, language and festivals were constantly mixing Indigenous, African and European elements. Many "typical" Peruvian expressions come from this process.

sites.title: Colonial Lima you can show on your tours
sites.lead: These places in the Historic Center of Lima are perfect to talk about the Viceroyalty while you walk with your group.

plazaArmasLima.name: Main Square of Lima
plazaArmasLima.description: Stage of political and religious power: here you find the government palace, the cathedral and houses of influential families.

catedralLima.name: Cathedral of Lima
catedralLima.location: East side of the Main Square
catedralLima.description: Main temple of the colonial city. A good place to talk about the role of the Church and architectural changes over time.

casaAliaga.name: Casa Aliaga
casaAliaga.description: Colonial mansion linked to the same family since the 16th century. Great to talk about elites, domestic life and continuity in Lima‚Äôs history.

sanFrancisco.name: San Francisco Convent and catacombs
sanFrancisco.description: Religious complex famous for its cloisters and catacombs. Ideal to explain the role of religious orders and spirituality in colonial times.

tips.title: Tips for explaining the Viceroyalty on tour
tips.lead: Use these ideas so colonial history feels alive instead of a dry list of dates.

items.ideaStory1: Start from the square: show how political, religious and economic power all meet in the same space.
items.ideaStory2: Connect the Viceroyalty with today: ask which surnames, churches or typical dishes come from that colonial mixture.
items.curiosity1: Lima was so important that for centuries it controlled territories that are now part of several South American countries.
items.curiosity2: Many "miraculous" images and saints combine European elements with Andean and African devotions.

tips.footer: Adjust the level of detail to the time you have and the group‚Äôs interest. Not every tour needs the same depth.

republica.title: Republic of Peru: crises, change and identity
republica.subtitle: From independence to the present, Peru has gone through wars, economic crises, internal migration and a lot of creativity. This stage helps you connect history with the modern Lima your visitors see.

keyIdeas.title: Key takeaways
keyIdeas.lead: To give a simple explanation of the Republic, these three ideas are usually enough.

bullets.one: Independence did not solve everything: the new State went through decades of instability and military strongmen.
bullets.two: The economy relied on export cycles (guano, saltpeter, minerals), which brought moments of wealth and also deep crises.
bullets.three: Modern Peru is built through internal migration, cultural mixing and a constant search for a shared identity.

timeline.title: Quick timeline
timeline.lead: Four moments to organize the republican period without overwhelming the group.

independence.label: Peruvian independence
independence.description: San Mart√≠n‚Äôs proclamation in Lima and later military campaigns by Bol√≠var and Sucre that secured independence.

earlyRepublic.label: First republican decades
earlyRepublic.description: Unstable governments, military caudillos and difficulties building a strong State with presence across the territory.

exportCycles.label: Export cycles
exportCycles.description: Periods of wealth thanks to guano, saltpeter and other exports, followed by crises, debt and conflicts like the War of the Pacific.

modernPeru.label: Contemporary Peru
modernPeru.description: Rural‚Äìurban migration, internal conflict, new constitutions and a changing urban life.

structure.title: How to explain the Republic in a simple way
structure.lead: You don‚Äôt need to list all presidents; it‚Äôs better to focus on these axes.

state.title: State and politics
state.text: The Republic tries to build its own institutions: constitutions, Congress, political parties. There are periods of democracy and also coups and authoritarian governments.

economy.title: Economy and models
economy.text: The country moves through different models: export of raw materials, attempts at industrialization, agrarian reforms and, later on, economic liberalization.

society.title: Society and inequality
society.text: Inequalities between coast, highlands and jungle remain, but middle classes grow, education expands and more groups participate in public life.

conflicts.title: Conflicts and memory
conflicts.text: External wars (like the War of the Pacific) and the internal conflict of the late 20th century leave deep scars. Today there is debate about how to remember them and what changes are needed.

life.title: Everyday life in the republican period

city.title: Lima and the modern city
city.text: Lima expands with new neighborhoods, transport, parks and shopping areas. It is the perfect stage to talk about the Peru visitors see today.

regions.title: Coast, highlands and jungle today
regions.text: Each region contributes different traditions, accents, foods and festivals. Many people move between regions in search of work and opportunities.

identity.title: Peruvian identity
identity.text: Cuisine, football, music, dances and festivities help create a shared identity, even though debates on racism, centralism and representation are still very present.

sites.title: Places to talk about the Republic in Lima
sites.lead: These spots in the city help you connect republican history with what the group is seeing right now.

plazaSanMartin.name: San Mart√≠n Square
plazaSanMartin.description: Square built to celebrate the centennial of independence. Ideal to talk about heroes, monuments and historical memory.

parqueReserva.name: Parque de la Reserva ‚Äì Magic Water Circuit
parqueReserva.description: Early 20th-century park adapted today with dancing fountains and a night show. A good example of how the city reinvents itself.

mirafloresMalecon.name: Miraflores clifftop walk & parks
mirafloresMalecon.description: Parks along the cliffs, bike lanes and Pacific Ocean views. Great to talk about tourism, urban life and contemporary Lima.

tips.title: Tips for explaining the Republic without becoming partisan
tips.lead: Your goal is not to share your personal opinion, but to give context so visitors can understand today‚Äôs Peru.

items.ideaStory1: Connect a specific place with a historical change, for example San Mart√≠n Square with independence and national celebrations.
items.ideaStory2: Ask the group what surprises them most about modern Lima and use that as a starting point to talk about migration, new neighborhoods and cultural mixing.
items.curiosity1: People born in all regions of Peru now live in Lima; many regional customs can be found in the capital.
items.curiosity2: Several "classic" Peruvian dishes, such as lomo saltado or pollo a la brasa, are republican creations that blend influences from different origins.

tips.footer: Keep a balanced tone: be clear with historical facts, avoid party politics and leave room for the group to form their own opinions.
